examples.sentence: 買う, 書く, 読む, etc.
食べる, 見る, 起きる, etc.

sections.heading: What is Dictionary Form?
sections.content:
Dictionary form (辞書形) is the basic, unconjugated form of a verb. It's called "dictionary form" because it's how verbs appear in dictionaries.

食べる (taberu) - eat 行く (iku) - go する (suru) - do

Also called: plain form , basic form , u-form

children.heading: 1. Casual Conversations
children.content:
With friends, family, people younger than you:

何食べる？ "What will you eat?" 映画見る？ "Will you watch a movie?" 明日行く "I'll go tomorrow"

children.heading: 2. Inner Thoughts/Narrative
children.content: 今日は何をしようかな... "What should I do today..." そろそろ帰る時間だ "It's about time to go home"

children.heading: 3. Grammar Patterns
children.content:
Many patterns require dictionary form:

食べることができる - can eat 行くつもりだ - intend to go 飲む前に - before drinking

children.heading: 4. Quoting/Reporting
children.content: 彼は行くと言った "He said he would go" 明日雨が降ると思う "I think it will rain tomorrow"

children.heading: 5. Modifying Nouns
children.content: 食べる人 - person who eats 行く時間 - time to go 読む本 - book to read

sections.heading: All Verb Groups in Dictionary Form

children.heading: Godan Verbs
children.content:
End in -u sounds:

書く (kaku) - write 読む (yomu) - read 話す (hanasu) - speak 買う (kau) - buy 待つ (matsu) - wait 遊ぶ (asobu) - play 飲む (nomu) - drink 帰る (kaeru) - return 泳ぐ (oyogu) - swim

children.heading: Ichidan Verbs
children.content:
End in -eru or -iru :

食べる (taberu) - eat 見る (miru) - see 寝る (neru) - sleep 起きる (okiru) - wake up 教える (oshieru) - teach 着る (kiru) - wear 出る (deru) - go out 開ける (akeru) - open

children.heading: Irregular Verbs
children.content: する (suru) - do 来る (kuru) - come

sections.heading: Polite vs Plain
sections.content:
Dictionary form is plain . Compare with polite:

| Dictionary (Plain) | Masu (Polite) | Meaning | | ------------------ | ------------- | ------- | | 食べる | 食べます | eat | | 行く | 行きます | go | | する | します | do | | 来る | 来ます | come | | 飲む | 飲みます | drink |

Important: Plain ≠ rude. Context matters!

sections.heading: Present/Future Tense
sections.content:
Dictionary form expresses both present and future:

毎日本を読む "I read books every day" (present habitual) 明日本を読む "I'll read a book tomorrow" (future)

Context determines which meaning.

children.heading: Making Suggestions
children.content: 一緒に行く？ "Want to go together?" これ食べる？ "Want to eat this?"

children.heading: Stating Intentions
children.content: 今日は早く帰る "I'm going home early today" 明日勉強する "I'll study tomorrow"

children.heading: Asking About Plans
children.content: 週末何する？ "What will you do this weekend?" どこ行く？ "Where are you going?"

children.heading: と思う (to think)
children.content: 明日雨が降ると思う "I think it will rain tomorrow" 彼は来ないと思う "I think he won't come"

children.heading: つもりだ (intend to)
children.content: 日本に行くつもりだ "I intend to go to Japan" 明日勉強するつもりだ "I intend to study tomorrow"

children.heading: ことができる (can/able to)
children.content: 泳ぐことができる "I can swim" 日本語を話すことができる "I can speak Japanese"

children.heading: 前に (before)
children.content: 食べる前に手を洗う "Wash hands before eating" 寝る前に本を読む "Read a book before sleeping"

children.heading: 時 (when/time)
children.content: 日本に行く時 "When I go to Japan" 食べる時 "When eating / Time to eat"

children.heading: な (prohibition)
children.content: ここで遊ぶな "Don't play here" それを食べるな "Don't eat that"

sections.heading: Modifying Nouns
sections.content:
Dictionary form can modify nouns directly:

読む本 - book to read 食べる物 - thing to eat 行く場所 - place to go 住む所 - place to live

children.heading: With の
children.content: 泳ぐのが好き "I like swimming" 料理するのは楽しい "Cooking is fun"

sections.heading: Negative Dictionary Form (ない-form)
sections.content:
Dictionary form has a negative counterpart:

食べる → 食べない (don't eat) 行く → 行かない (don't go) する → しない (don't do) 来る → 来ない (don't come)

More on this in the Nai-form lesson.

sections.heading: Question Sentences
sections.content:
Add か or use rising intonation:

明日来る？ "Are you coming tomorrow?" これ食べる？ "Will you eat this?" 日本語分かる？ "Do you understand Japanese?"

sections.heading: Formal Writing
sections.content:
Dictionary form appears in:

- Newspaper headlines - Academic writing - Technical manuals - Signs and notices

Example:

本日休業する "Closed today" (sign)

children.heading: Mistake 1: Using Plain Form in Formal Situations
children.content:
Wrong: 先生、明日行く ❌ Right: 先生、明日行きます ✓ Wrong: これ食べる？ (to boss) ❌ Right: これを食べますか？ ✓

Use polite forms with superiors!

children.heading: Mistake 2: Confusing with Polite Form
children.content: Dictionary: 食べる (casual) Polite: 食べます (formal) Don't mix: 食べるます ❌

children.heading: Mistake 3: Wrong Conjugation Base
children.content: Wrong: Using dictionary form where te-form needed 食べる + ください → 食べてください ✓ (Not: 食べるください ❌)

children.heading: Godan Verbs
children.content: All end in -u sound 買う, 書く, 読む, etc.

children.heading: Ichidan Verbs
children.content: End in -eru or -iru 食べる, 見る, 起きる, etc.

children.heading: Irregular
children.content: する, 来る

children.heading: With ください
children.content: Wrong: 食べるください ❌ Right: 食べてください ✓

children.heading: With いる/ある (present progressive)
children.content: Wrong: 食べるいる ❌ Right: 食べている ✓

children.heading: With た (past tense)
children.content: Wrong: 食べるた ❌ Right: 食べた ✓

children.heading: Casual Conversation
children.content: 今日何する？ "What are you doing today?" 一緒に映画見る？ "Want to watch a movie together?" 明日は休む "I'm taking tomorrow off"

children.heading: With Grammar Patterns
children.content: 日本語を勉強することが好きだ "I like studying Japanese" 彼は来ると言った "He said he would come" 食べる前に祈る "Pray before eating"

sections.heading: Key Takeaways
sections.content:
✓ Dictionary form = basic, unconjugated verb ✓ Used in casual speech and grammar patterns ✓ NOT rude, but inappropriate in formal situations ✓ Expresses both present and future ✓ Required for many grammar constructions ✓ Can modify nouns directly ✓ Found in dictionaries (hence the name)

Master dictionary form - it's the foundation for all other conjugations!

Next: Masu Form (Polite Present)

Related:

Verb Groups Nai-form (Negative) Te-form Conjugation
